title: 105_hr1171
content:
The Clean Coal Technology program is repealed, but authority is preserved for obligations related to projects selected by the Secretary of Energy. Unobligated funds for the program are rescinded. Additionally, the Overseas Private Investment Corporation is terminated. The Overseas Private Investment Corporation's authority to issue new obligations will be terminated 60 days after the enactment of the Act. This includes insurance, guaranties, loans, and securities acquisitions. The Corporation itself will be abolished 180 days after the Act's enactment. Operations will be transferred to the Office of Management and Budget. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will take over the functions of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation for contracts and agreements until their expiration, without renewing them. Title IV of chapter 2 of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 will be repealed, but will still apply to functions performed by the Director. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will take over the functions of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation for contracts and agreements until their expiration, without renewing them. Funds available to the Corporation will be transferred to the Director for use in performing these functions. Any unexpended balances of the transferred funds will be deposited in the Treasury. The repeal of certain provisions of law will not affect prior determinations. The repeal of certain provisions of law will not affect any orders, regulations, or contracts issued before the effective date of the repeal. These orders and contracts will remain in effect until modified or terminated by authorized officials or by law. Pending proceedings before the Overseas Private Investment Corporation will also continue unaffected by the repeal. The repeal of certain provisions of law will not affect any orders, regulations, or contracts issued before the effective date of the repeal. Such proceedings related to functions performed by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget after the repeal shall continue as if the Act had not been enacted. Orders issued in these proceedings will remain in effect until modified, terminated, superseded, or revoked by the Director, a court, or by operation of law. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget is authorized to issue regulations for the transfer of proceedings. The Act will not affect suits commenced before the repeal, and proceedings will continue as if the Act had not been enacted. Liabilities incurred by officers will not be affected by the repeal. The enactment of this section does not abate any proceeding involving officers of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. Suits involving the Corporation or its officers will continue with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget as a party if necessary. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget's orders and actions in the Overseas Private Investment Corporation are subject to judicial review. Statutory requirements for notice, hearings, and administrative review apply to the Director's functions. Technical amendments are made to Title 5 of the United States Code. The Overseas Private Investment Corporation undergoes statutory amendments to remove specific positions and make technical changes to Title 5 of the United States Code. Several statutory amendments were made to Title 5 of the United States Code, including the removal of specific positions and technical changes. Several statutory amendments were made to Title 5 of the United States Code, including changes to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the Foreign Operations, Export Financing, and Related Programs Appropriations Act, 1996. The Democracy Act of 1989 was amended to include the Administrator of the Agency for International Development. The amendment applies to the annual report required under the Foreign Operations, Export Financing, and Related Programs Appropriations Act, 1996. Additionally, Section 2(c)(12) of the Support for East European Democracy Act of 1989 was repealed. Section 202(b)(2)(B) of the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 is amended by removing clause (iv) and redesignating clauses (v), (vi), and (vii). Section 9101(3) of title 31, United States Code, is amended by removing subparagraph (H) and redesignating subparagraphs (I) through (P). The provisions of law repealed include Section 5(b)(2) of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation Amendments Act of 1981 and Section 5 of the Taiwan Relations Act. The amendments made by this subsection include references to various sections of different Acts, with an effective date of 180 days after enactment. The Congress believes the US should not participate in the latest round of the IMF General Agreements to Borrow. The Congress finds that the IMF operates with little public scrutiny, imposes conditions on loans, enforces unsound economic policies on developing nations, and bailing out governments encourages detrimental policies. The Congress finds that the IMF enforces detrimental policies on developing nations, such as destroying natural resources and overspending on militaries. It is recommended that the United States should not participate in the latest round of IMF funding. The Congress finds that the IMF's Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF) makes low-interest loans to poor countries, but these loans often do more harm than good, leading to increased poverty. Therefore, it is the sense of the Congress that the United States should not provide additional resources to the ESAF. TITLE V--TRANSPORTATION PROGRAMS

SEC. 501. SENSE OF CONGRESS CONCERNING HIGHWAY DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS.

Congress acknowledges that highway demonstration projects, which increased significantly under ISTEA, have limited economic benefits, often do not align with transportation priorities, are not included in state plans, and divert funds from other important highway programs. Congress believes that these projects should not be mandated by Federal law. SEC. 502. ELIMINATION OF APPALACHIAN DEVELOPMENT HIGHWAY SYSTEM PROGRAM. Repeals Section 201 of the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 and makes conforming amendments to Section 401 of the Act.
